BASIC STATISTICS


Distribution of Samples

How is the distribution of bread weight data?

You need a frequency diagram to answer this question. Then, the next question becomes the number of intervals or interval width.

Let the interval width be 1 gr. for this sample.

Many statistical software can automatically calculate the number of intervals (bins) and interval width, for the optimum graphical demonstration.

BASIC STATISTICS


STATISTICS


  • Statistics is a set of scientific principles and techniques that are useful in reaching conclusions about populations and processes when the available information is both limited and variable; that is, statistics is the science of learning from data.

    Statistical Methods and Data Analysis, 2001, R. Lyman Ott, Michael Longnecker


  • Samples should be representative of the population.


    17

    BASIC STATISTICS


    Population vs. Sample Statistics


    Population

    Sample

  • Descriptive parameters (used for populations)

    • Population: a dataset that consists of measurements of all

      the members of some group.

    • Descriptive parameters are used to describe the

      population.


  • Sample statistics

    • Samples: a dataset which consists of measurements of

      only a portion of the members from some population.

    • Sample statistics are used to draw inferences about the

entire population from the measurements of a sample.


18

BASIC STATISTICS


Measures of Location: Central Tendency


MODE

The mode of a set of measurements is defined to be the measurement that occurs most often (with the highest frequency).

If the data is graphed in a histogram or a dot plot, the midpoint of the interval of the highest bar or stack represents the mode.


MEDIAN

The median of a set of measurements is defined to be the middle value when the

measurements are arranged in order of magnitude.

ARITHMETIC MEAN

A “Weighted” Average

Each measurement is weighed by its frequency of occurrence


29

BASIC STATISTICS


A Measure of Normality: Anderson-Darling


Anderson-Darling Normality Test

Compares the actual data frequency distribution with a theoretical normal distribution calculated by using sample estimates for  and а.


Calculates a test statistic called A2 which should be small if the

theoretical distribution fits the data distribution.


P-value: is the likelihood that the test statistic A2 could be as big as

it is if the data set came from a normal distribution.


40

BASIC STATISTICS


Anderson Darling Normality Test


  • Anderson Darling Normality Test

    • Used to determine whether or not data is normally distributed.

    • Null hypothesis: Data follow normal distribution, Ho = Data is Normal

    • Alternative hypothesis: Data not follow normal distribution,

      Ha = Data is NOT Normal.


  • P-Value

    • Indicates that the probability of a random sample from a normally distributed population would deviate from normal as much as, or more than your sample.

    • High p-value indicates you should fail to reject the null hypothesis that the data is representative of a normal distribution.

    • Generally, unless P-Value is less than 0.05, you should fail to reject null

41 hypothesis.

BASIC STATISTICS


ChamberTemp.mtw

Homework


A technician is responsible for hospital equipment sterilization process. One of critical parameters is temperature in “sterilization” process cycle.

Specification Limits for temperature: 123.50C-126.50C

A study was conducted to estimate the Capability of Sterilization Process. For seven days, every day the temperature of the five consecutive sterilization cycles were measured. Data from 35 measurements are in “ChamberTemp” file.

What is your estimate for temperature being in tolerance limits. Find

the probability of a single measurement to be in the specification.



56

BASIC STATISTICS


Process Variation


  • All processes display variation. None of the outputs is identical with another.

  • There are two sources of variation:

    • A steady component that is inherent to the process that Dr. Shewhart attributed to chance and undiscoverable “common” causes - random variation (like the variation in the two parts produced consecutively)

    • An intermittent component, seen over time, attributed to assignable “special” causes

      that could be economically discovered and removed.

  • Process outputs follows a certain pattern or shape if the process is stable over time.

  • Concepts like location or variation are meaningful when data

distribution has a shape.

61

    BASIC STATISTICS


    The Difference Between Ppk – Cpk

  • Ppk: includes the effects of both within group variations and between group

    variation

  • Cpk: Includes only the effect of within group variations

    • It is the answer to “What if the sub-group means would be the same”.

BASIC STATISTICS


SIGMA LEVEL


For one sided tolerances:

Sigma Level = Z-Score


For two sided tolerances: bring all the defects together on the

same side of the distribution then calculate new Z-Score Sigma Level = Z-Score (calculated over total error rate)

FridgeWidth.mtw

BASIC STATISTICS


Homework 2


  • Standard single door refrigerators are manufactured in the assembly line. One of the critical parameters controlled is refrigerator width.

  • Specification limits for the width 700 mm ± 1 mm.

  • To analyze the capability, a technician measured samples for 7 days by subgroups of 5 each day.

  • Calculate process capability and interpret the results.


    77

    BASIC STATISTICS


    Long Term vs. Short Term


    • Even excellent processes may show small variation over time.


    • By convention, this long-term variation is defined as a 1.5 а correction in the short- term.


      Estimated


      • A 6а short-term process is considered a 4.5а long- term process.

BASIC STATISTICS


The “Entitlement” of a Process


Process Entitlement:

The best case, short term defect level of a process when all input variables in the process are centered and in control



Entitlement
